title: Who will Hillary Clinton pick as her vice presidential running mate?
preds: Question has been resolved, can Good Judgement close this question ? Hillary picked TK as her VP pick. http://edition.cnn.com/2016/07/22/politics/hillary-clinton-vp-pick/

Hillary Clinton Selects Tim Kaine, a Popular Senator From a Swing State, as Running Mate
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/23/us/politics/tim-kaine-hillary-clinton-vice-president.html

The issue with Clintons decision is that if she goes for the senators with re-elections coming up then democrats may loose to the republicans  in those states . I think she would avoid those senators .
But if she was going to pick her first choice it would be Kaine. her choice for vp will be a person, who  is older & more experienced than some on the list.
This is primarily based on the current news media reports.
Up another 15% for TK. Wish HRC had asked for my advice. ;-)
Moving up on Kaine per the consensus. Still think Booker or Warren have a small shot.

7/22/16: As an official 'announcement' may come today or tomorrow, going mainly with the current media etc. consensus, for the moment.  Sources considered: http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/22/politics/hillary-clinton-vp-pick/index.html https://www.predictit.org/Market/1530/Who-will-win-the-2016-Democratic-vice-presidential-nomination
It's getting late for a new name to come up.

Another reason for Vilsack: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/hillary-clinton-tom-vilsack_us_57910f5fe4b0fc06ec5c20b9?section= Just look at the guy -- if Trump wants to campaign on fear, Vilsack oozes a sense of security --with a resume to back it up.
Adjusting since the smart money is on TK. Won't matter much for scoring since we'll know very shortly.

Reports list Kaine as the late favorite after Trump selects Pence.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/sen-kaine-seen-as-clintons-vp-pick-1469144626
There are two questions, what would be the best choice. The second is what will HRC do. I'm gradually trying to focus on the latter.

My somebody else is Tom Vilsack.  Vilsack is an 8 year cabinet veteran, is from the heartland and is needed to offset Pence.  He could make a Lloyd Bentsen-styele "I knew ____ and you're no ___" and get away because he has more substance than Pence. Mother Jonze and those who follow them are not comfy with him. http://www.motherjones.com/environment/2016/07/hillary-clinton-vilsack-veep-food-agriculture-companies%20 Perez would be "leftist cannonfodder" for racista Trumpeteers as this NR link indicates http://www.nationalreview.com/article/436112/tom-perez-leftist-radical-hillary-clinton-vp-shortlist Kaine has been DNC chairman during the Obama salad days and just 3 years as a Virginia senator, but may have the wrong stuff to make GOP anti-Trump voters and influencers feel comfy with idea he is "one of us."   He is a Beltway insider-operator and there needs to be a connection to the heartland on the Clinton ticket to help offset Donnie's lunatic fringe of useful idiots;)  http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/07/tim-kaine-vice-president-hillary-clinton-virginia-senate Castro has the right stuff to win "Latino" votes but lacks the "substance" or "seasoning" to be a credible VP, much as Marco Rubio lacks the substance that it takes to be president. http://www.latimes.com/nation/politics/trailguide/la-na-republican-convention-2016-live-a-potential-clinton-running-mate-slips-1468871684-htmlstory.htmlboi The choice boils down to old fashioned "clientist" politics.

If HRC wants someone with national security credentials and/or who can help her secure a swing state, Stavridis would seem to be the best choice.  I think HRC decided to make the announcement in FL independently of her decision of who to select as her running mate, but it so happens that Stavridis is from FL.

Obama prefers Kaine, but Vilsack is more loyal to Hillary than Kaine is, and the campaign is not worried about Trump taking Virginia (he has a shot in Iowa).    I really thought Booker had a good shot (as Hillary will need the black vote in North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania in order to win), but I think Hillary is becoming more confident in the Trump campaign's incompetence and so it diminishes his chances (plus he is not as loyal to the Clinton machine as Vilsack or even Kaine).
Tom Vilsack is reported to be near the top.  Watching his debate performances, I can see why. He's good.

It will not be a female. She has that vote. I think it will be a more moderate person, someone that could get conservative votes or mobilize black people to vote. Elizabeth Warren has been talked about alot, an all female ticket would give her zero advantage.

Kaine and Warren have not been scheduled to speak at the convention yet and ALL THE OTHER vp PICKS ON THIS LIST HAVE BEEN.
http://www.cnbc.com/2016/07/18/howard-dean-reads-tea-leaves-on-clinton-vp-pick-focusing-on-2-names.html

At this point, best guess is "safe-pick" Kaine.  A mild(?) "surprise" not listed above (e.g., Vilsack, Hickenlooper) seems possible.  Per the first two sources considered below, "progressive panic" re Trump (i.e., favorable for Clinton) plus Trump's choice of "extreme" Pence may render less important perceived need for Clinton to 'lean left' with her V.P. choice. (I.e., to appease Sanders followers.) ...That is, if many really care about a V.P. pick much at all (last source below). Sources: http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/trump-panic-drives-progressives-toward-clinton-225667 http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/07/17/pence-trump-clinton-kaine-running-mate/87217604/ http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/tim-kaine-hillary-clinton-vp-insiders-225634 https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/07/18/newslflash-voters-may-not-care-who-donald-trump-or-hillary-clinton-pick-for-vice-president/

The Washington Post gives a nice summary of VP options for Hillary: https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/clinton-has-these-vp-options-fiery-liberals-hispanics-and-white-guys/2016/07/17/f13bb3ec-4c17-11e6-a7d8-13d06b37f256_story.html  This appears to indicate that Timothy Kaine would be a relatively safe option.  In light of Trump's pick for VP this actually makes some sense.

There are 2 points of view... Pence allows Hillary to go more liberal to help with the Bernie fans: http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/07/17/pence-trump-clinton-kaine-running-mate/87217604/
And that Trump's pick of Pence allows Hillary to move to the middle. I'm thinking the second view is very Clinton-esque.
http://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/elections/2016/07/17/pence-trump-clinton-kaine-running-mate/87217604/

Warren and Booker give her nothing she doesn't already have-- except, in the case of Warren, an all-female ticket, which is intriguing. Kaine is the best all-around person on the list, in terms of likability and accomplishment. Castro would be a historic first Hispanic AND a person with solid domestic policy credentials.
Vilsack and Perez are underestimated possibilities.

Tim Kaine will potentially pull white male voters from rural areas and the south. This is where Clinton is weakest.  Alternatively, Cory Booker could excite the young liberal base, another group she really needs to support her.
Adjusting for Vilsack and the unknown. http://www.nbcnews.com/politics/2016-election/potential-clinton-vp-tom-vilsack-best-kept-secret-politics-n610631

Castro and Perez are the two candidates that most obviously create a contrast to Trump. They further the already established narrative of "Make America White Again" without having to say anything. And obviously helps solidify Democratic ownership of the Hispanic vote now and for future campaigns.
EW is too valuable in the Senate and as an excellent attack dog, Tim Kaine it is.
Julian Castro is too young and inexperienced. Elizabeth Warren needs to remain in the Senate. Timothy Kaine simply has a better set of skills, including Spanish.

More and more, I think it will be Kaine.  Warren and Brown are not happening because of the Senate, Booker and Castro would be a win with constituents that are already won.  I'm pretty sure it will be Kaine.  Adjusting numbers. http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/287641-clinton-torn-between-caution-and-risk-in-vp-pick

Hillary Clinton will attempt to pick an elected official from a battle ground state, a governor would probably be better so Timothy Kaine would be better since Sherrod Brown's longevity in the senate would leave him vulnerable. She will feel no need to pick Julian Castro or Cory Booker since it is very unlikely that the Hispanic or Black vote will change from its historical patter. Elizabeth Warren seems like she would be a good choice to shore up Bernie Sanders but her progressive image may not have widespread appeal to moderate voters and white blue collar workers.

Is Warren part of HRC's selection team?
http://www.cnn.com/2016/07/15/politics/hillary-clinton-elizabeth-warren-vp-meeting/index.html

Governor Pence on the other ticket means either another midwesterner (Brown) or another swing state person (Kaine or Warner, both out of Virginia) for Clinton.  (Full disclosure:  My Clinton people have stopped talking to me, which suggests the choice has been made.  Don't know who The Lucky Winner is, though--see "stopped talking to me," supra.)   She doesn't need Warren, Booker, or Castro (all of whom can be awarded cabinet posts), in their respective demographics or states.  Meantime, I'll take Warren for Treasury; Castro for Interior, which is a bump up from HUD; and Booker for maybe DHHS, although it's not a very good gig to quit the Senate for--maybe Booker for UN ambassador (think Andy Young, not to be any more racialist than strictly necessary in the circs).   Do recall that I have been wrong so often this year that even my daughter is starting to doubt my infallibility....
need positive person who can fight against trump

Tim Kaine has a wide scope of experience (state governor in a red/purple state, US Senator, foreign policy experience). He is level headed and has respect across both parties. Virginia has a sitting Democratic Governor, so would likely appoint a Democratic replacement. Elizabeth Warren would super-energize the Democratic party, but may have some drawback for some independent and cross-over voters. Massachusetts sitting Governor is republican so would likely replace Warren with a republican. (-1 for Senate seats). Vice Presidential position might actually be constraining for Warren who could a far more visible platform as a Senator.
OK, I'm upping TK 20%. Who am I to contest the consensus although this article seems about right: http://thehill.com/homenews/campaign/287641-clinton-torn-between-caution-and-risk-in-vp-pick
Most of the 39% in "Someone else" is Tom Perez.
In a perfect world HRC will select Bernie: that would be enough.

I'm going stronger on Someone Else -- and I still think it could be Vilsack. (I don't believe I'm saying this) He could help with the white male vote.
 https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/powerpost/paloma/daily-202/2016/07/14/daily-202-keep-an-eye-on-tom-vilsack-in-hillary-clinton-s-veepstakes/57870a37cd96926bdf4092b6/  Possible other: Tom Perez. http://www.politico.com/story/2016/07/clintons-new-friend-and-maybe-vp-225347
Aggregate of many wisdoms of crowds

Adjusting up TK and SE by 5%, primarily for scoring purposes. Still think not having some excitement/energy (like EW) will be a major mistake. What do I know? — and we've seen that sometimes really smart people still make really bad decisions. Perhaps it is time for a shake-up in the HRC campaign, but probably wouldn't be in time for the VP decision.
She will pick a minority or a woman other than Warren. Duval patrick or Cory Booker. Warren will be replaced by a republican and isn't nearly as popular among black people in swing states.

-In a poll last week conducted by Selzer & Co. for Bloomberg Politics, just 5 percent of Clinton supporters said Kaine would be the best possible pick. Six percent suggested Brown, 12 percent said Castro, 17 percent said Booker and 35 percent said Warren. -finances of Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro, Sen. Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts and Sen. Timothy M. Kaine of Virginia. tom Kaine- Another plus: Virginia has a Democratic governor who would appoint his replacement, so his departure from the Senate wouldn't be a net loss for the party -No chance there is an all female ticket (85% no) - Tim Kaine, Cory Booker and Xavier Becerra were invited Tuesday to speak at the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia, sources familiar with the planning of the event told The Huffington Post. _ Kaine speaks spanish , goes to predominately black church , safe pick

http://www.npr.org/2016/07/12/481556964/meet-hillary-clintons-potential-vice-presidents-in-100-words Moving up on "Someone else" and trying not to let my personal preference for Warren cloud my forecast:)
Downgrading Elizabeth Warren. Upgrading Kaine and Brown as they seem they might be able to head off white working class support to Trump

Dropping Warren down to 5% after Bernie's endorsement of HRC. I think a double lady ticket is taking too much risk at this stage without the potential payoff. It's either Kaine or someone else who HRC will not have problems working with. Based on the current polls, I don't think she really needs the candidate to bring additional voters to her, although that is seen as a bonus for most VP candidates. HRC will prefer someone who will play ball, rather than someone who has a competing connection with the voters.  Raising Se to 45% from 10%.

I've been guessing this since 1988. Yet to get one right. So zero confidence in my ability to guess what one person(and it is just one person's call) will do.   Castro, too young.
Warren and Brown, have to be able to govern with them. Politicly and personally not compatible with the boss lady.
Kaine, Mr easy going, can get along with anyone. A centrist, like HRC. 
Booker, a wild card. More centrist on trade and Wall Street, like HRC is when she owns up real positions. 
(Se), I'm hearing Sec Perez. He's not a politician, but he has a fair amount of polish. And I think he's like Kaine, Mr easy going.

Sigh, coming down on Warren based on this speculation:
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/us/politics/elizabeth-warren-hillary-clinton-vp.html?&moduleDetail=section-news-2&action=click&contentCollection=Politics&region=Footer&module=MoreInSection&version=WhatsNext&contentID=WhatsNext&pgtype=article And this longshot....
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/us/politics/james-stavridis-hillary-clinton-vice-president.html?action=click&contentCollection=Politics&module=RelatedCoverage&region=EndOfArticle&pgtype=article

HRC mostly set with minorities, progressives, Wall Street, business (managed to keep anti TPP rhetoric out of the Dems platform), the Military, important allies and the female vote.  Warren has been used in attacks against Trump; not really presented in VP light during the  campaign, and could out HRC during the campaign.  Although some reports list Warren as a last resort option, if needed, against Trump, HRC does not appear to be in enough trouble for that.  HRC seem to be weak with white male voters, young Sanders voters and has some credibility issues. Of the publicly listed candidates, Kaine (with some trust issues) and a new candidate, James Stavridis (4 years as the NATO Supreme Aalied Commander) could bring the moderate fringe of the GOP.  
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/13/us/politics/james-stavridis-hillary-clinton-vice-president.html S.Brown, Booker are Senators that may be tough to replace in states with GOP gov's.
Tim Kaine and Sherrod Brown are both pretty safe picks with little chance of overshadowing Hilary.

Some how I see Clinton with  warren as Vice President , they look good together. 
Lets hope she picks the most qualified person.

After reading other's comments re Sherrod Brown's Democratic Senate seat being filled by a Republican governor, I downgraded my estimate for Brown and added those points to Tim Kaine, a good "safe" pick for Hillary, but not electrifying like Warren.

Kaine is the most likely because he has no downside other than blandness. A senator that would be replaced by a Democratic governor. Warren is popular and her selection would result in a quick election for her replacement by Massachusetts law. Booker is the strongest personal pick in many ways, but would be replaced by a Republican's selection, making him not ideal. Brown is in the same boat while being politically attractive but not personally attractive to Clinton (is my instinct). Casto is neither attractive nor plausible by resume. Someone else is fairly strong because no one listed is a slam dunk (and contains the rest of the population).

Kaine appears to be the consensus “safe” choice, while Warren appears to be the consensus risky choice. Per @alanne (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/277551), Warren vacating her senate seat would lead to a Republican taking her place.

I think we underestimate Castro. HCR launched her bid for Senate after her then President husband pardoned the PR separatists, and in their long game - Castro would be in line for the White House after a 8 year share of a second Clinton Presidency. It would also solidify the voting bloc behind the Dems and defend against inroads on that bloc by the Republicans over that same eight year time frame and help deliver big Senate seats to her as well.

It's been only three hours and I am already changing my mind on this question!
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/278180 I expect HRC will opt for Kaine over Warren, since a double lady ticket is kinda difficult for the electorate to swallow. Also, Bernie has already said he will support her run for Presidency. Think that somewhat reduces the pressure to go for Warren. Keeping 10% for someone else since this is a crazy election cycle and 1% for everyone else.

Taking a big risk on this question. Don't know anything about the people listed here, but GJO consensus is that it is either EW and TK. Also, I think HRC is less likely to spring a surprise on the voters with the VP nominee than Trump. Caution is that if Trump picks his VP first, she may be forced to pick a counter candidate which could still end up as a surprise. However, I think Trump is likely to pick his candidate later than HRC, which means HRC is likely to pick one of the leading 'known' contenders. Going 50-50 between TK and EW.

Kaine
Virginian (strong on law, order and military and will help to sway the state towards dems) +1
Stronger establishment resume (experience with government) +1
General appeal (appeal to independents) +1
Blue collar roots (working class appeal) +1
Caucasian male (perception and reality of privilege) -1 (contrast with Clinton on gender) +1 Warren
From progressive state (no net gain) -0.5
Progressive (plays well to base which needs energising) +1
Demonstrated capacity to play Trump +1
Strong economic credentials +1
Caucasian female (perception and reality of privilege compared with racial minority) -0.5 (lack of contrast with Clinton on gender) -0.5 (strong female leader) +1 Keane appears to be the safer choice for middle America appeal. 
Warren appears to be the safer choice for appeal to progressive America. If Trump and his choice does not lock in the republican base, a candidate that has greater appeal to the republican base would provide a better advantage.
If Trump and his choice lock in the republican base, a candidate appealing to the progressive democrats would provide a better advantage.

not Warren - http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2016/07/hillary-clinton-elizabeth-warren-vice-president-tpp yes Kaine (law, necessity military operation against ISIS) - http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/07/tim-kaine-vice-president-hillary-clinton-virginia-senate not Castro (mortage sale criticism) not Brown (opinion of good judgment members, controversinal remarks in 2011) - http://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2016/05/hillary-clintons-narrowing-vice-presidential-pool/484133/ not Booker (may go to Supreme court) - http://edition.cnn.com/2016/07/03/politics/cory-booker-hillary-clinton/index.html

HC has been media testing EW for weeks now, and EW seems to be the most prominent surrogate (in terms of media time, public speaking appearances, etc.) among all these possible running mates. EW is also the closest to Bernie on policy, and would best help the Hillary campaign win the support of people who voted for Bernie in the primaries. After Warren, the most likely picks for joining HC at the top of the ticket are white, male Dems who can give her a lift among white voters--particularly white men--in key battleground states (SB in Ohio, TK in Virginia).

I actually have no idea other than to assume that Hillary campaign will see that selecting Warren will be a welcome change from the business as usual: ZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZZzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz..........................
She will not pick a senator from a state with a Republican governor

(no change) Most comments seem very useful. HRC could really use some excitement about the whole ticket. The only one to fit that bill is EW. Agree with @Anneinak that the possible short term loss of a D Senator is something that can be managed.

http://www.mydaytondailynews.com/news/news/state-regional-govt-politics/ohioans-possible-vp-picks-for-hillary-clinton/nrwDb/ "If Republicans maintain control [of the Senate], they can block her [Clinton's] nominees to the U.S. Supreme Court and her cabinet, while killing her budget and tax plans. By picking Brown, Clinton would be handing the seat over to the Republicans. By contrast, Massachusetts’ law provides for a relatively swift special election to replace Warren.
~~~~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I consider control of the Senate a powerful argument, lethal for Brown.

I think she will ultimately go with a safe and pragmatic pick.  Julian Castro has too little experience and Elizabeth Warren probably does as well, though she is quite popular among democrats.  Booker and Brown seem like good picks but I think Clinton will weigh the fact that the democrats would lose their senate seats.  I wouldn't sleep on other picks, Perez and Becerra being the most likely.  But Kaine seems to be the safest, and the odds-on favorite.
Will adjust as convention gets closer. Figure with all the Democratic senators and governors (about 65), there's a higher probability of someone not among these five Democrats being selected.
Hillary does not need another woman on the ticket.    She already has the female vote garnered.   I think she will go with a latino to lock up the latino vote.

Senators from states with R governors would compromise control of Senate. Julian Castro light resume and lackluster record at HUD. Kaine will be embraced by business leaders still not won over by Clinton but scared of Trump. Allows Clinton friend McAuliffe honor of appointing next VA senator.
I'd really like Warren but she is not in a swing state and isn't a minority.
Juste read that Castro wasn't on the short list .
Well there is no need for the democrats to risk losing a seat in the senate.
Age, race, complementary to Hillary, uncertainty of Trump's VP pick

Surprisingly hard.  There really isn't a standout nominee, when you consider the impact to the Senate.  Both Warren and Brown would be replaced by Republican Senators (at least for a while).  And this election is all about the Senate.  The next President and Senate will change the Supreme Court for years to come.  Thus, low probabilities for Warren and Brown.  Castro is good, but he helps lock up Hispanics and other minorities that Clinton already has locked up.   As mentioned in the Huff Post article below, Kaine is a "do no harm" (i.e., be cautious) candidate, and that is the definition of the Clinton race.  I think it will be Kaine. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/richard-north-patterson/the-2016-veepstakes-who-w_b_10609488.html
http://www.oddsshark.com/entertainment/usa-presidential-election-2016-vice-president-odds
http://www.2016election.com/2016-running-mate-odds/
EW up 10%. Cokey Roberts might be wrong about two women on the ticket. Definitely more energy with her!

Filling a need.  The need is not adding to African-American vote nor Mexican vote.  But Ohio yes.
Win Ohio and start picking out the curtains you want in the White House.

One thing I've been thinking about is that whoever Hillary picks is going to have to contend with Bill.  He won't be an ordinary presidential spouse!  Male.  Former president.  A but-in-ski.  Not very respectful of boundaries.   Not very disciplined.   I can't see him taking up reading to kindergarteners, launching a healthy food choice or "just say no" to drugs campaign, or a fitness program!!!!   Or a wildflower/roadside beautification project.   Being the male vp of a female pres will be a hard enough row to hoe, adding Bill as the first-spouse will really make it a challenge for anyone's ego. . . possibly an unpleasant one. Most men I know would find what would amount to being #3 in the White House, unappealing, and intolerable because of  their egos.  I think a woman might find Bill more tolerable & manageable than a man would, and being vp to a female pres more interesting & desirable.  When I saw how Hillary was just beaming when she was campaigning with Warren, I thought, That's the one she should choose."  Warren helps her with trade issues, brings the Sanders vote, and brings PASSION & EXCITEMENT to the campaign that is in danger of strangling itself with facts, figures and policy proposals presented in a flat, deep droning voice.  With a male running mate, Clinton would be her stiff self:  with Warren, she comes alive.

We will most surely know the answer to the market far in advance of the 1 September closing date as the Democratic Convention starts on 25 July. 
https://demconvention.com/about-the-convention/

If you've ever seen Elizabeth Warren and Hillary on the stage together you get why this is her best possible choice.  When the two of them are on stage, Hillary lights up in a way that she really needs to in order to electrify the electorate and ensure victory over Trump.

It is a logical choice. Ms. Warren is very powerful in the DNC, with a certain "connectedness" to Sander's views and having been director of the Consumer Finance Protection Bureau.
   Ms. Warren appears to have been vetted with a meeting at Hilary's home, and the two have appeared together at campaigns.
Up 5% TK since he is campaigning some with HRC next week.

Vilzack. I'm a little partial -- bein' from Iowa and all, but I thought he would be a good choice when HC first announced. He'll not make the progressive folks feel all warm and fuzzy, and I'm not sure he would be that good of "attack dog," but I think he could go a long way

It's NUTS that this doesn't include Tom Perez who has been stumping for Clinton. I'm guessing he has an 18% chance, and the rest of the "Someone else" split among Garcetti, Ryan (the Democratic one), and Becerra.

According to this http://www.aol.com/article/2016/07/08/hillary-clinton-narrows-vp-list-to-5-people/21426833/
we're down to Kaine, Warren, Brown, Vilzack, Perez
The last two are not on the list above.
Two women on a ticket? Unlikely
Booker is best bet to get "black" fence sitters.   Brown is the most qualified, but is chosen only if Ohio is a problem.

Great finally to see this question. Fun no matter what the scoring is. Only two real contributions. JC's actual resume (even if possible past scandals are a non-issue) is a bit weak. Second, Cokey Roberts (NPR) opined recently that a woman as VP would trigger negative reactions (bias even if subtle) toward women at the top of the ticket. If not for that aspect which I would not have considered beforehand, I'd have EW higher.

These are all pretty good people, as is Mark Warner, who isn't on the list and so is my "someone else" avatar.  I think she needs geographic support rather than demographic.  She will do well among blacks, Hispanics, and women no matter what.  She will carry Jersey and Massachusetts no matter what, and will not carry Texas no matter what.  Brown is well regarded and well connected in Ohio, always a swing state and this year maybe more than ever, and Kaine is from Virginia, which should be close but will probably go for Clinton anyway.   Mark Warner, very well thought of in Virginia, has the charm of being an actually successful business person married only once, rather than a three-time loser on both counts like, oh let's say, Clinton's opponent--and also his opponent if Hair Boy goes with Newt.
